t: Job 3
Job Laments His Birth
After*p this Job opened his mouth and cursed the day of his birth.
And Job said:
“Let*pn the day perish on which I was born, and*ld the night that said, ‘A*ld man is conceived.’
Let*ln that day be darkness! May*ld God above not seek it, nor*ld light shine upon it.
Let*ln gloom and deep darkness claim it. Let*ld clouds dwell upon it; let*ld the blackness of the day terrify it.
That*ln night— let thick darkness seize it! Let*ld it not rejoice among the days of the year; let*ld it not come into the number of the months.
Behold,*ln let that night be barren; let*ld no joyful cry enter it.
Let*ln those curse it who curse the day, who*ld are ready to rouse up Leviathan.
Let*ln the stars of its dawn be dark; let*ld it hope for light, but have none, nor*ld see the eyelids of the morning,
because*ln it did not shut the doors of my mother’s womb, nor*ld hide trouble from my eyes.
“Why*pn did I not die at birth, come*ld out from the womb and expire?
Why*ln did the knees receive me? Or*ld why the breasts, that I should nurse?
For*ln then I would have lain down and been quiet; I*ld would have slept; then I would have been at rest,
with*ln kings and counselors of the earth who*ld rebuilt ruins for themselves,
or*ln with princes who had gold, who*ld filled their houses with silver.
Or*ln why was I not as a hidden stillborn child, as*ld infants who never see the light?
There*ln the wicked cease from troubling, and*ld there the weary are at rest.
There*ln the prisoners are at ease together; they*ld hear not the voice of the taskmaster.
The*ln small and the great are there, and*ld the slave is free from his master.
“Why*pn is light given to him who is in misery, and*ld life to the bitter in soul,
who*ln long for death, but it comes not, and*ld dig for it more than for hidden treasures,
who*ln rejoice exceedingly and*ld are glad when they find the grave?
Why*ln is light given to a man whose way is hidden, whom*ld God has hedged in?
For*ln my sighing comes instead of my bread, and*ld my groanings are poured out like water.
For*ln the thing that I fear comes upon me, and*ld what I dread befalls me.
I*ln am not at ease, nor am I quiet; I*ld have no rest, but trouble comes.”
